newsitem.title: USA: Georgia tax fails in Cobb County, passes elsewhere.
newsitem.headline: Georgia tax fails in Cobb County, passes elsewhere.

text.p: Voters in Georgia's Cobb County dealt a stunning defeat Tuesday to a one percent sales tax for school improvements, while sales tax increases and extensions passed in nine smaller Georgia counties.
By a vote of 18,820 to 14,204, Cobb County and Marietta voters became the first in the Atlanta metropolitan area to reject a sales tax for schools.

The proposal, which sparked a flurry of cable TV and local radio adds by an opposition group, would have increased the sales tax to 6 percent to raise an estimated $654 million for school construction, renovation, technology and bond debt relief.

Georgia voters approved a constutitional amendment in November allowing school districts to levy a one-percent sales tax for five years to fund construction and repay bond debt. The tax must also be approved locally by referendum.
Voters in six other counties approved the school tax in their elections Tuesday.
In Crisp County, the tax would raise $16.5 million and was approved 734 to 476.
In Dougherty County, the tax would raise $90.4 million and was approved 4,351 to 3,065.
In Hall County, the tax would raise $132.5 million and was approved 5,986 to 1,371.
In Lowndes County and Valdosta voters approved the tax 3,504 to 2,141. It will raise up to $89 million, to be split between the city and county schools.
In Peach County, the tax would raise $10 million and was approved 1,762 to 281.
In Worth County, the tax would raise $9.8 million and was approved 1,048 to 347.
Three counties also approved five-year extensions of their one-cent local option sales taxes for other projects.
In Bulloch County, the extension would raise $35 million for landfill, road and bridge projects and was approved 957 to 359.
In Chatham County, the tax would raise $230 million for drainage and road projects and was approved 10,770 to 9,912.
In Oglethorpe Couunty, the tax would raise about $3 million for roads and infrastructure projects and was approved 769 to 60.
